On Web Typography

`Tale of a dev obsessed with typography and readability on the web`

Luca Gesmundo
Nov 7 ¬∑ 5 min read

Web Typography obsessed me. As many others, I fell in the trap of optimizing legibility. Definetly not an easy task.
Among all the contenders for the best reading experience around the Web, a name is always present and master (?) of the scene: Medium.com .

Looking for the arcane secrets that regulates good legibility, I immediately reckon that I needed to walk in the footsteps of the greatests. So I started dissecting the rules that makes Medium typography, well, great.
There were long hours of tremendous effort, days and days of prolonged pains.

Now I want to share with you the results of those long hours ü¶ã

An unexpected journey

Comes out that nothing is better than a big first letter to super-charge your style. Rules are simples. A big letter that spans exactly two rows. Play with line-height to get it right.

The hero

When designing a website you have to take into account fonts for three applications: the content, the UI, the brand.

Content font

The content font should be a serif one, to make our eyes gently brougth from one letter to the other with the lowest amount of effort.
Line-height and letter-spacing are vital here. Play with those parameters to make the most out of your font of choice. However at Medium you'll find almost an empty line of space in the middle of two lines of text. Letter-spacing is a little bit on the negative side to make words more compacts.

Brand font

The purpose of this font is to enforce the presence of our brand during the navigation experience. We can use it for titles and, here and there, for some minutiae.

Blockquotes, for example ü§´

UI font

The font used for alle the UI elements is preferably a sans-serif one. It should create contrast with the content font. Its color could be a little bit lighter than the one used for the main content. It needs to be readable given the background-color of your page but not distracting from the main purpose of the page. Reading!

The highlight

To highlight a word or phrase you can wrap them in a span element and set the background to a color that reminds of your brand color identity.

Every Title

`Needs a subtitle`

Here we find rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.54) to give meaningful informations without grabbing the attention that the title, main charachter, deserves.

The length

The length of a line of text should never be longer than 740px. So our eyes are not forced to run from left to right on the page.

The color

The text color should be rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.84) on a rgba(255, 255, 255, 1) background to ensure the best contrast possible.

Conclusion

As always, the strict first rule of design is that there are no strict rules.
